text: It's a busy Friday evening, and there's a power outage in the neighborhood, leaving half the kitchen appliances without power. The kitchen is already working at full capacity, and now orders are getting delayed. Front-of-house staff are getting anxious as customers keep asking for updates. The temperature in the kitchen is rising, and you can sense stress levels increasing among your team members. With limited equipment and a full restaurant, what would be your course of action to handle this situation?

options.text: Step away briefly to see if you can expedite restoration of power and trust the team to manage things until you return.
Delegate to the most experienced cook to determine the new priorities and best use of limited equipment while you ensure the rest of the staff stays focused.
Take the time to briefly gather the team, explain the situation, and brainstorm solutions with them, allowing everyone to contribute ideas and make decisions as a team.
Prioritize cold dishes that don't require power, clearly assign each cook a role in preparing those dishes, and personally handle communication with the front-of-house staff to keep them informed.
Focus on keeping customers happy by managing front-of-house communications while instructing your team to improvise and figure out how to manage without key appliances.

Have a direct, one-on-one conversation with the more experienced cook, asking them to adjust their approach and manage the issue without further conflict.
Ignore the situation for now, trusting that the two cooks will eventually work things out on their own without any intervention.
Take both line cooks aside individually to understand their perspectives and mediate a solution that works for both, ensuring you also check in with them later to see how it's going.
